title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is my first post in a Quarto blog.
The world is my oyster.
Next stop: the moon.

title: Assignment 5 continued
text:
In this continuation of Assignment 5, I will combine all the ballots from my classmates into 1 using a scoring system. If the player is ranked 1, they get 10 points. Rank 2 gets 7 points and so on like this:
Rank 1- 10 points Rank 2- 7 points Rank 3- 5 points Rank 4- 3 points Rank 5- 1 point
Then we will see who has the highest score, and they will be on the final ballots.
First all ballots need to be gathered, rearranged, and combined.
Obtain Sharon’s ballot, which is the gold standard for formatting:


Code
Sharon <- readRDS("C:/Users/sharo/Desktop/BCB 520/BCB520/posts/Mar_20_ballots/sharon_ballot.rds")
Sharon |> mutate(Award = str_replace_all(Award, c("Frank Selke Memorial" = "Frank", 
                                                  "Calder Memorial"="Calder",
                                                  "Hart Memorial"="Hart",
                                                  "James Norris Memorial" = "James",
                                                  "Lady Byng Memorial"="Lady"))) -> Sharon


Obtain Barrie’s ballot and adjust.


Code
Barrie <- read_excel("C:/Users/sharo/Desktop/BCB 520/BCB520/posts/Mar_20_ballots/Barrie.xlsx")

Barrie |>
  mutate(Award = str_replace_all(Award, c("Selke" = "Frank", "Byng" = "Lady", "Norris" = "James"))) -> Barrie


Obtain Betsy’s ballot and adjust.


Code
Betsy <- read_excel("C:/Users/sharo/Desktop/BCB 520/BCB520/posts/Mar_20_ballots/BetsyChurchHockeyBallot.xlsx")
Betsy |> relocate(`Player Name`, .before=Name) |>
  relocate(`Nomination position`, .before=Name) |>
  rename(
    Player = `Player Name`,
    Rank = `Nomination position`,
    Voter = Name
  ) |>
  mutate(Award = str_replace_all(Award, c("Selke" = "Frank", "Byng" = "Lady", "Norris" = "James"))) -> Betsy


Obtain Justice’s ballot and adjust.


Code
Justice <- read_excel("C:/Users/sharo/Desktop/BCB 520/BCB520/posts/Mar_20_ballots/Book 10.xlsx")
Justice |> fill(Award) |>
  group_by(Award) %>%
  mutate(Rank = rep(1:5, length.out = n()), Voter = "Justice") %>%
  ungroup() |>
  rename(Player = `Top 5 Individuals`) %>%
  select(Player, Rank, Voter, Award) -> Justice

Justice |> 
  mutate(Player=strsplit(as.character(Player), "-")) |>
  unnest(Player) |>
  mutate(Award = str_replace_all(Award, c("Hart Memorial" = "Hart", "Vezina Trophy" = "Vezina", 
                                          "James Norris Memorial"= "James", "Calder Memorial"="Calder", 
                                          "Frank J Selke"="Frank"))) |>
  filter(!is.na(Player)) -> Justice


Obtain Marwa’s ballot and adjust.


Code
Marwa <- read_excel("C:/Users/sharo/Desktop/BCB 520/BCB520/posts/Mar_20_ballots/Book 11.xlsx")
Marwa |> mutate(Award = str_replace_all(Award, c("Hart Memorial Trophy" = "Hart", "Vezina Trophy" = "Vezina", 
                                          "James Norris Memorial Trophy"= "James", "Calder Memorial Trophy"="Calder", 
                                          "Frank J. Selke Trophy"="Frank", "Lady Byng Memorial Trophy"="Lady"))) -> Marwa


Obtain Claire’s ballot and adjust.


Code
Claire <- read.table("C:/Users/sharo/Desktop/BCB 520/BCB520/posts/Mar_20_ballots/CS_ballot.txt", header = TRUE, sep = ",", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

Claire |> mutate(Award = str_replace_all(Award, c("Heart" = "Hart", 
                                          "James Norris"= "James", 
                                          "Frank J. Selke"="Frank", "Lady Btng"="Lady"))) |>
  select(Player, Rank, Voter, Award) -> Claire


Obtain Ian’s ballot and adjust.


Code
Ian <- read_excel("C:/Users/sharo/Desktop/BCB 520/BCB520/posts/Mar_20_ballots/IAN HOCKEY NOMINATIONS.xlsx")


New names:
• `` -> `...3`


Code
Ian |> select(Voter, Trophy, Player) |>
  group_by(Trophy) |>
  mutate(Rank=row_number()) |>
  ungroup() |>
  mutate(Award = str_replace_all(Trophy, c("Hart Memorial" = "Hart", 
                                          "James Norris"= "James", "Calder Memorial"="Calder",
                                          "Frank J Selke"="Frank", "Lady Byng"="Lady"))) |>
  select(Player, Rank, Voter, Award) -> Ian


Obtain John’s ballot and adjust.


Code
John <- read.table("C:/Users/sharo/Desktop/BCB 520/BCB520/posts/Mar_20_ballots/JohnCam.txt", header = TRUE, sep = ",", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

John |> mutate(Voter="John") |> 
  mutate(Award = str_replace_all(Award, c("James Norris"= "James",
                                          "Frank J. Selke"="Frank", "Lady Bing"="Lady"))) |>
  rename(Rank = Place) |>
  select(Player, Rank, Voter, Award) -> John


Obtain Henry’s ballot and adjust.


Code
Henry <- read_excel("C:/Users/sharo/Desktop/BCB 520/BCB520/posts/Mar_20_ballots/NHL award ballot HT.xlsx")
Henry |> mutate(Award = str_replace_all(Award, c("James Norris"= "James",
                                          "Frank J. Selke"="Frank", "Lady Byng"="Lady"))) |>
  mutate(Voter = ifelse(Voter == "Henry Trujillo", "Henry", Voter)) -> Henry


Obtain Priya’s ballot and adjust.


Code
Priya <- read_excel("C:/Users/sharo/Desktop/BCB 520/BCB520/posts/Mar_20_ballots/NHL_Award_ballet.xlsx")
Priya %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = -c(Voters, Rank), names_to = "Award", values_to = "Player") %>%
  mutate(Voters = ifelse(Voters == "'\"'", "Priya", Voters)) |>
  mutate(Voter="Priya") |> select(-Voters) |>
  mutate(Award = str_replace_all(Award, c("VEZINA"= "Vezina",
                                          "HART"="Hart",
                                          "JAMES NORRIS"="James",
                                          "CALDER"="Calder",
                                          "FRANK J SELKE"="Frank",
                                          "LADY BING"="Lady"))) |>
  select(Player, Rank, Voter, Award) -> Priya


Everyone’s combined ballots (head only)


Code
everyone <- rbind(Barrie, Sharon, Betsy, Claire, Henry, Ian, John, Justice, Marwa, Priya)

everyone |>
  mutate(Player = str_squish(Player)) %>%
  mutate(Player = ifelse(str_detect(Player, " "), 
                         word(Player, -1), 
                         Player)) |>
  mutate(Player = ifelse(Player == "Caufieldn", "Caufield", Player)) |>
  mutate(Player = ifelse(str_detect(Player, "^Go"), "Gostisbeher", Player)) -> everyone
head(everyone)


# A tibble: 6 × 4
  Voter  Award  Player      Rank
  <chr>  <chr>  <chr>      <dbl>
1 Barrie Hart   Hughes         1
2 Barrie Hart   Werenski       2
3 Barrie Hart   Makar          3
4 Barrie Hart   Draisaitl      4
5 Barrie Hart   Kucherov       5
6 Barrie Vezina Hellebuyck     1


The final scores (head only)


Code
everyone |>mutate(Score = case_when(
    Rank == 5 ~ 1,
    Rank == 4 ~ 3,
    Rank == 3 ~ 5,
    Rank == 2 ~ 7,
    Rank == 1 ~ 10,
    TRUE ~ 0  # default case if Rank is not 1-5
  )) |> 
  group_by(Award, Player)|>
  summarise(sum(Score)) -> finalscore


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Award'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


Code
head(finalscore)


# A tibble: 6 × 3
# Groups:   Award [1]
  Award  Player     `sum(Score)`
  <chr>  <chr>             <dbl>
1 Calder Bolduc                7
2 Calder Brink                10
3 Calder Clurman              10
4 Calder Cooley                6
5 Calder Cotter                1
6 Calder Crookshank            5




Code
finalscore <- finalscore %>%
  rename(sumscore = `sum(Score)`)


Create final ballots for each award
I acknowledge ties in the scores and choose not to do anything about them.
Calder Memorial


Code
finalscore |> filter(Award=="Calder") |>
  arrange(desc(sumscore)) |>
  slice_head(n=5) |>
  mutate(Rank=row_number()) -> final_ballot_calder

final_ballot_calder


# A tibble: 5 × 4
# Groups:   Award [1]
  Award  Player    sumscore  Rank
  <chr>  <chr>        <dbl> <int>
1 Calder Marchenko       55     1
2 Calder Johnston        45     2
3 Calder Rossi           24     3
4 Calder Holloway        16     4
5 Calder Johnson         12     5


Frank Selke


Code
finalscore |> filter(Award=="Frank") |>
  arrange(desc(sumscore)) |>
  slice_head(n=5) |>
  mutate(Rank=row_number()) -> final_ballot_Frank

final_ballot_Frank


# A tibble: 5 × 4
# Groups:   Award [1]
  Award Player     sumscore  Rank
  <chr> <chr>         <dbl> <int>
1 Frank Tanev            20     1
2 Frank Blake            17     2
3 Frank MacKinnon        15     3
4 Frank Tuch             14     4
5 Frank Zetterlund       14     5


Hart Memorial


Code
finalscore |> filter(Award=="Hart") |>
  arrange(desc(sumscore)) |>
  slice_head(n=5) |>
  mutate(Rank=row_number()) -> final_ballot_hart

final_ballot_hart


# A tibble: 5 × 4
# Groups:   Award [1]
  Award Player      sumscore  Rank
  <chr> <chr>          <dbl> <int>
1 Hart  Draisaitl         38     1
2 Hart  MacKinnon         22     2
3 Hart  Gostisbeher       21     3
4 Hart  Kucherov          21     4
5 Hart  Werenski          14     5


James Norris


Code
finalscore |> filter(Award=="James") |>
  arrange(desc(sumscore)) |>
  slice_head(n=5) |>
  mutate(Rank=row_number()) -> final_ballot_James

final_ballot_James


# A tibble: 5 × 4
# Groups:   Award [1]
  Award Player   sumscore  Rank
  <chr> <chr>       <dbl> <int>
1 James Makar          21     1
2 James Hughes         20     2
3 James Cole           18     3
4 James Werenski       15     4
5 James Bouchard       13     5


Lady Byng


Code
finalscore |> filter(Award=="Lady") |>
  arrange(desc(sumscore)) |>
  slice_head(n=5) |>
  mutate(Rank=row_number()) -> final_ballot_lady

final_ballot_lady


# A tibble: 5 × 4
# Groups:   Award [1]
  Award Player   sumscore  Rank
  <chr> <chr>       <dbl> <int>
1 Lady  Point          25     1
2 Lady  Karlsson       21     2
3 Lady  Makar          20     3
4 Lady  Eichel         14     4
5 Lady  Connor         10     5


Vezina memorial


Code
finalscore |> filter(Award=="Vezina") |>
  arrange(desc(sumscore)) |>
  slice_head(n=5) |>
  mutate(Rank=row_number()) -> final_ballot_vezina

final_ballot_vezina


# A tibble: 5 × 4
# Groups:   Award [1]
  Award  Player      sumscore  Rank
  <chr>  <chr>          <dbl> <int>
1 Vezina Hellebuyck        90     1
2 Vezina Vasilevskiy       57     2
3 Vezina Thompson          28     3
4 Vezina Blackwood         19     4
5 Vezina Wolf              12     5


I am going to rename Frank to Selke, James to Norris, and Lady to Byng because I don’t know why I chose the first names. Last names sound better.
Here is the final compiled ballot:


Code
final_ballot <- rbind(final_ballot_calder, final_ballot_Frank, final_ballot_hart, final_ballot_James, 
                      final_ballot_lady, final_ballot_vezina)

final_ballot <- final_ballot |> 
  mutate(Award = case_when(
    Award == "Frank" ~ "Selke",
    Award == "James" ~ "Norris",
    Award == "Lady" ~ "Byng",
    TRUE ~ Award  # Keep other entries unchanged
  ))

final_ballot


# A tibble: 30 × 4
# Groups:   Award [6]
   Award  Player     sumscore  Rank
   <chr>  <chr>         <dbl> <int>
 1 Calder Marchenko        55     1
 2 Calder Johnston         45     2
 3 Calder Rossi            24     3
 4 Calder Holloway         16     4
 5 Calder Johnson          12     5
 6 Selke  Tanev            20     1
 7 Selke  Blake            17     2
 8 Selke  MacKinnon        15     3
 9 Selke  Tuch             14     4
10 Selke  Zetterlund       14     5
# ℹ 20 more rows

title: Assignment 5
text:
Here are my selections for the hockey trophies listed and described below in each section.
For each award, I have created a ballot of five players, ranked from 1 (first choice) to 5 (fifth choice). For each ballot, I have provided one to three visualizations that explain and justify the ballot.

title: Assignment 5
text:
Vezina ballot
Once the data is filtered by > 40 games played and > 1100 saves, it seems like the best discerning feature would be % Saves (if I understand the data correctly). Once those are all sorted out, the top 5 players below will be on my Vezina Trophy ballot.
The vezina ballot:


Code
Vezina_ballot <- Goalie |> select(Player, GP, Shots.Against, Saves, SV.) |>
  filter(GP > 40) |>
  filter(Saves > 1100) |>
  arrange(desc(SV.)) |>
  mutate(Rank=row_number()) |>
  slice_head(n=5)
  
Vezina_ballot


               Player GP Shots.Against Saves   SV. Rank
1   Connor Hellebuyck 46          1262  1170 0.927    1
2  Andrei Vasilevskiy 48          1335  1232 0.923    2
3 Mackenzie Blackwood 44          1229  1125 0.915    3
4     Igor Shesterkin 44          1263  1144 0.906    4
5        Ilya Sorokin 45          1237  1117 0.903    5

title: Assignment 5
text:
Hart Memorial ballot
After consideration, it seems to me that there is not an appreciable difference between playing 54 and 62 games, so that will not be considered. The only factor I will consider needed is GF, because this already sorts out players who have only played a small number of games. Therefore I will take the top 5 in the GF category:
The hart memorial ballot:


Code
hartmemorial_ballot <- OnIce.Skater |> select(Player, GF, GP) |>
  arrange(desc(GF)) |>
  slice_head(n=5) |>
  mutate(Rank=row_number())

hartmemorial_ballot


            Player  GF GP Rank
1 Nathan MacKinnon 116 61    1
2   Leon Draisaitl 109 60    2
3  Nikita Kucherov 109 57    3
4       Cale Makar 109 61    4
5      Jack Eichel 106 59    5

title: Sharon
text:
This is my BCB520 portfolio.
This is a little bit about me:

title: Sharon
text:
Experience
2017-2024 | Alturas Analytics, Inc. Senior Scientist/Principal Investigator for the LC-MS/MS bioanalytical phase of pharmaceutical preclinical and clinical trials
2012-2017 | Alturas Analytics, Inc. Associate Scientist/Scientist: developing and and validating LC-MS/MS assays to support the pharmaceutical industry
2011, 2012 | BP Exploration Alaska: 12-week summer process engineering internships

title: Sharon
text:
Education
2008-2012 | B.S. in Chemical Engineering from Washington State University

title: Sharon
text:
Interests
Mountains: climbing them, looking at them.

title: BCB 520 Assignment 3
text:
Herein lies BCB 520 assignment 3, which contains an infant fecal microbiome correlation plot.
What does that mean?
First, a little bit about the data: I have a data table that contains participants (first column, 21 rows of participant IDs), and bacterial genera read counts averaged over 9 timepoints per participant. There were initially over 1000 bacterial genera columns of data, but I have trimmed it down to the top 30.
Before I go on, we will load libraries and take a peek at the data table.

title: BCB 520 Assignment 3
text:
Correlation plot
Below is a raw plot. Note the dark diagonal line that corresponds to correlation 1. This represents something compared to itself (like Bacteriodes to Bacteriodes mentioned above).
Each circle represents the direction and magnitude of the correlation as described by the legend on the left. Strong correlations are indicated with a large, dark circle. Blue means positive correlation, red means negative correlation.
But wait- I have a better one below. I felt that this plot may be useful to understand what rcorr is doing before I trim it down to what is actually interesting (to me).

corrplot(IF_IF_rcorr$r, pch.col='black', pch.cex=0.7,
         method=c("circle"), tl.cex=0.5)
mtext("Infant Fecal Microbiome Correlation- Basic", line =3)








Now in order to improve the usefulness of the graphic, I have done several things:
Remove the upper triangle. You may notice that the upper and lower triangles are mirror images, so this is just redundant data.
Remove the 1-1 correlations (the dark blue diaganol). The fact that something is 1-1 correlated with itself is not useful or interesting.
Flag significant p values, because it would be nice to know which correlations are actually statistically significant. One star represents a “trend” (p < 0.05) and two stars indicate a significant correlation (P < 0.01). [Don’t people usually say p < 0.05 is significant? Yes, but this is exploratory data, and we just wanted a rough way to correct for false discovery rate. Don’t get me started on p value adjustments for correlation matrices. It’s a living nightmare.]
I have also clustered the correlations with similar direction and magnitude using “Angular order of the Eigenvectors” (AOE). Basically that groups dots with similar colors and sizes together. There are other clustering methods, but I don’t understand them well enough to know which is the best.

title: Assignment 4
text: Some good and some bad plots.

title: Assignment 4
text:
Figure 1
4 different color hues effectively separate the type of bacterial genera.
The length of the bar clearly shows the relative amounts of each genera.


Code
g1 <- ggplot(IF_top30, aes(x= Subject, y= Abundance, fill=Bacteria)) +
  geom_bar(stat="identity") +
  labs(title="Figure 1: Top 4 baby poop bacterial genera in 12 healthy infants",
       x="Subject",
       y="Relative Abundance")+
  theme_bw()

g1

title: Assignment 4
text:
Figure 2


Code
IF_top30_2 <- readRDS("IF_top30.rds")

IF_top30_2 <- IF_top30_2 |> rownames_to_column(var="Subject")




Code
IF_top30_2 |> pivot_longer(
  cols=-Subject,
  names_to="Bacteria",
  values_to="Abundance") -> IF_top30_2


Figure 2 contains a lot more data, but many of these bacterial relative abundances are zero and the tallest line is the Unclassified genera.
“The importance of the attribute should match the salience of the channel”- in this case the large unclassified block and the inclusion of far too many genera impact the effectiveness of this plot.


Code
g2 <- ggplot(IF_top30_2, aes(x= Subject, y= Abundance, fill=Bacteria)) +
  geom_bar(stat="identity") +
  labs(title="Figure 2: Baby poop bacterial genera",
       x="Subject",
       y="Relative Abundance")+
  theme_bw()

g2

title: Assignment 4
text:
Figure 3


Code
FA_relabund <- readRDS("FA_relabund_avg_no_overlap.rds")
FA_relabund |> rownames_to_column(var="Subject") -> FA_relabund




Code
FA_relabund_bysat <- readRDS("FA_bysaturation.rds")

sub1_sat_FA <- FA_relabund_bysat |> filter(Participant=="A003") |>
  pivot_longer(cols=-Participant, names_to = "Fatty_acid", values_to = "Abundance")

sub1_sat_FA <- sub1_sat_FA |> mutate(label=paste0(round(Abundance,1),"%"))




Code
#pie chart

sub1_bysat_pie <- ggplot(sub1_sat_FA, aes(x="",y=Abundance, fill=Fatty_acid))+
  geom_bar(stat="identity", width=1)+
  coord_polar("y", start=0)+
  geom_text(aes(label=label), size=3, position=position_stack(vjust=0.5),
            check_overlap = T)+
  theme_void()+
  labs(title="Fatty Acid Composition by Saturation Level for Subject 1",
       fill="Fatty Acid")+
  theme(legend.position="right")

sub1_bysat_pie

title: Assignment 4
text:
Figure 4


Code
sub1_FA <- FA_relabund |> 
  filter(Subject=="A003") |>
  pivot_longer(cols=-Subject, names_to="Fatty_acid", values_to = "Abundance") |>
  mutate(label=paste0(round(Abundance,3),"%")) |>
  arrange(desc(Abundance)) |>
  mutate(Fatty_acid = factor(Fatty_acid, levels=Fatty_acid))




Code
#pie chart

sub1_pie <- ggplot(sub1_FA, aes(x="",y=Abundance, fill=Fatty_acid))+
  geom_bar(stat="identity", width=1)+
  coord_polar("y", start=0)+
  geom_text(
    aes(label=label),
    position=position_stack(vjust=0.5),
    check_overlap = T,
    size=3
  )+
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option="H")+
  theme_void()+
  labs(title="Fatty Acid Composition by individual fatty acid for Subject 1",
       fill="Fatty Acid")+
  theme(legend.position="right")

sub1_pie

title: Assignment 4
text:
Figure 5
I think we can clearly distinguish both stronger and weaker correlations, and also the direction of correlation.


Code
IF_top30_fresh <- readRDS("IF_top30.rds")
IF_IF_rcorr <- rcorr(as.matrix(IF_top30_fresh[1:20,1:20]), type=c("spearman"))




Code
corrplot(IF_IF_rcorr$r, p.mat=IF_IF_rcorr$P, sig.level=c(0.01,0.05), 
         insig='label_sig', pch.col='black', pch.cex=0.7,
         method=c("circle"), tl.cex=0.5, order="AOE", type="lower", diag = F)
mtext("Infant Fecal Microbiome Correlation with AOE Cluster (6 mo avg)", line =3)

title: Assignment 4
text:
Figure 6
I think that the little triangles of light blue and light orange cannot be distinguished. This plot also contains redundant data (upper and lower triangle) which makes it hard to know what is actually important.


Code
IF_IF_rcorr2 <- rcorr(as.matrix(IF_top30_fresh[1:20,1:20]), type=c("spearman"))

corrplot(IF_IF_rcorr2$r, pch.col='black', pch.cex=0.7,
         method=c("pie"), tl.cex=0.5)
mtext("Figure 6 - messy shapes that can barely be distinguished", line =3)

title: Assignment 4
text:
Extra
I think the ellipses are terrible.


Code
corrplot(IF_IF_rcorr2$r, pch.col='black', pch.cex=0.7,
         method=c("ellipse"), tl.cex=0.5)
mtext("Extra: ellipses", line =3)

title: BCB 520 Assignment 2
text:
Herein lies BCB 520 assignment 2, where I describe some fecal microbiome data.
I have chosen an infant fecal microbiome relative abundance dataset. This data contains the top 30 most abundant bacterial genera, from 21 infants, averaged over 9 collection timepoints. The read counts are expressed as a percentage of the total read counts (relative abundance). The name of this file is IF_top30.rds.
I have also included Infant_Fecal_Relabund.rds which is the less processed version of IF_top30.rds. It has not been averaged across timpepoint, or selected for the top 30.

title: BCB 520 Assignment 2
text:
Create correlation matrix

IF_IF_rcorr <- rcorr(as.matrix(IF_top30), type=c("spearman"))

title: BCB 520 Assignment 2
section: Correlation plot 1 - square matrix, no p values, 30x30
text:
Correlation plot 1 - square matrix, no p values, 30x30

corrplot(IF_IF_rcorr$r, method=c("circle"), tl.cex=0.5, order="AOE")
mtext("Infant Fecal Microbiome Correlation with AOE Cluster (6 mo avg)", line =3)

title: BCB 520 Assignment 2
section: Correlation plot 2 - lower triangle only, with p values starred, 30x30
text:
Correlation plot 2 - lower triangle only, with p values starred, 30x30

corrplot(IF_IF_rcorr$r, p.mat=IF_IF_rcorr$P, sig.level=c(0.01,0.05, 0.1), 
         insig='label_sig', pch.col='black', pch.cex=0.7,
         method=c("circle"), tl.cex=0.5, order="AOE", type="lower", diag = F)
mtext("Infant Fecal Microbiome Correlation with AOE Cluster (6 mo avg)", line =3)

title: BCB 520 Assignment 2
section: Correlation plot 3 - lower triangle only, with p values starred, 20x20
text:
Correlation plot 3 - lower triangle only, with p values starred, 20x20

corrplot(IF_IF_rcorr$r[1:20,1:20], p.mat=IF_IF_rcorr$P[1:20, 1:20], sig.level=c(0.01,0.05, 0.1), 
         insig='label_sig', pch.col='black', pch.cex=0.9,
         method=c("circle"), tl.cex=0.5, order="AOE", type="lower", diag = F)
mtext("Infant Fecal Microbiome Correlation with AOE Cluster (6 mo avg)", line =3)
